questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy with complaints of bedwetting. On asking history, she informs that he does this about 3 to 4 times per week. On further evaluation, he has a normal urine stream, daytime urine continence, and no history of UTIs. His physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use of enuresis alarm

 

This child has primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting in a child 5 years with no underlying medical cause). He has normal daytime continence, normal urinary stream, and no history suggesting infection or structural abnormality. After ruling out organic causes, the most effective first-line management is behavioral therapy with enuresis alarm. These alarms condition the child to wake up at the sensation of a full bladder, and they have the highest long-term success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound of abdomen: Indicated if there are signs of structural urinary tract disease, recurrent UTIs, abnormal urinary stream, or daytime incontinence. Since the child has normal examination and no such history, ultrasound is unnecessary.

 

Option B. Reassurance: While reassurance may be appropriate in very young children (<5 years) or when frequency is rare, this boy is 8 years old and wets the bed 34 times a week, making active intervention necessary.

 

Option D. Desmopressin acetate: This can be used if enuresis alarm fails, or when rapid control is needed (eg, sleepovers, camps). However, it has a higher relapse rate compared to alarm therapy, so it is not the first-line choice for long-term management.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs and its indications is matched incorrectly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bromocriptine Treatment of precocious puberty

 

Bromocriptine is primarily used for hyperprolactinemia and Parkinsons disease, not precocious puberty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Octreotide Treatment of diarrhea associated with vasoactive intestinal peptide tumors: Octreotide is correctly indicated for VIPoma-associated diarrhea.

 

Option C. Desmopressin Treatment of diabetes insipidus: Desmopressin treats central diabetes insipidus.

 

Option D. Leuprolide Treatment of infertility: Leuprolide is used in assisted reproduction for infertility management.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office due to several days of right ear pain. This morning she had 2 episodes of dizziness and almost fell. The patient is currently taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for an uncomplicated urinary tract infection. She has had no subjective fever, vision loss, or headaches. Temperature is 37C (98.6F), blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. Ear examination reveals several erythematous vesicles in the right external auditory canal with no drainage. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact. There is mild right-sided facial droop. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella zoster virus

 

This patient has right ear pain, erythematous vesicles in the external auditory canal, dizziness, and ipsilateral facial droop.

 

These findings are classic for Ramsay Hunt syndrome (Herpes zoster oticus):

 

  • Cause: Reactivation of latent Varicella zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion of CN VII.
  • Triad:
    1. Auricular pain + vesicles in ear canal/pinna
    2. Facial paralysis (lower motor neuron type)
    3. Vestibulocochlear symptoms (vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss)

 

So the most likely cause is Varicella zoster virus.

 

 

Vesicle in the auditory canal and auricle of the patient of Ramsay hunt syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas:

 

  • Causes malignant otitis externa (especially in elderly diabetics).
  • Presents with severe ear pain, granulation tissue, sometimes cranial nerve palsies if advanced.
  • But vesicular rash and acute facial droop are not typical.

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1):

 

  • Causes herpes labialis and occasionally encephalitis.
  • Not associated with vesicles in the ear canal and facial palsy.

 

Option C. Keratosis obturans:

 

  • A benign condition due to accumulation of keratin in the external auditory canal.
  • Causes ear blockage and conductive hearing loss, not vesicles or facial palsy.
